caseAdamscy.title: The Adamski Case: Orientation
caseAdamscy.summary: The Adamski family reported a subtle yet growing isolation and devaluation campaign by the head of the household.
content: The analysis starts with daily observations: locked doors, hijacked conversations and tight control over the family schedule.
Attempts to fracture bonds appear — gifts for selected members, criticism of the rest and threats to cut off funds.
The turning point arrives when the youngest daughter logs remarks and neighbours confirm the behavioural shift.
tips: Keep notes on everyday interactions, even the mundane ones.
Compare accounts from different family members — narcissists split people into factions.
Watch for sudden acts of kindness preceded by episodes of humiliation.

calendarAnalysis.title: Calendar Analysis: Chronicle of Escalation
calendarAnalysis.summary: A technique that records micro-events to reveal the full cycle of psychological abuse.
content: Keep a daily log of incidents and tag them with colour codes according to the type of harm.
After 30 days, a frequency map emerges showing phases of idealisation, devaluation and silence.
Comparing the victim and abuser calendars exposes correlations between promises and punishments.
tips: Use a single log to avoid losing track of data.
Add brief quotes or tone descriptions — critical for analysis.
Review entries weekly with a trusted person or therapist.

princeIngratitude.title: The Prince of Ingratitude: Narcissist Weapon
princeIngratitude.summary: A strategy of suddenly withdrawing favour after idealisation to force complete submission.
content: The narcissist scripts a fairy-tale scenario: promises of promotion, joint ventures or elevated status. The victim receives a 'prince' title.
Once trust is absolute, support disappears and public shaming follows.
The trap works because the victim defends an imagined status rather than the relationship itself.
tips: Check whether offered privileges have legal or financial grounding.
Notice demands for gratitude without actual help.
Define your own success criteria instead of adopting the abuser's narrative.

timeline.note: The victim is humiliated in front of witnesses.

investigationDocs.title: Investigation: Documenting Manipulation
investigationDocs.summary: A safe evidence-gathering protocol that avoids escalation while protecting the victim.
content: Create an incident diary with dates, times and sources: texts, emails, voice notes.
Set up a storage protocol — encrypted cloud or offline drive.
Add third-party statements and institutional records (school, doctor, employer).
tips: Do not alert the abuser if retaliation is likely.
Partner with local support groups to secure legal backup.

mythology.title: Mythology of the Narcissist
mythology.intro: Four warning symbols describing control cycles: 7 — ideal pact, 4 — dependency grid, 8 — return loop, 13 — rupture alert.

7.title: Seven
7.subtitle: Symbol of the perfect pact
meaning: Promise of an exceptional agreement beyond social norms.
Declarations of total loyalty in exchange for control.
when: When the narcissist proposes a secret collaboration or 'special' deal.
During sudden gifts after conflict periods.
Right before asking for a risky act of loyalty.
action: Ask about real consequences and request time to reflect.
Consult a trusted person before accepting the terms.

4.title: Four
4.subtitle: Symbol of the closed network
meaning: Four pillars of dependency: emotions, money, reputation, access to loved ones.
Signals a setup where every choice has four control levers.
when: When financial help requires reporting every expense.
When the abuser dictates who may be your friend.
action: Map alternative support outside the abuser.
Split dependencies: separate budget, alternate communication channels.
Secure at least one pillar today.

8.title: Eight
8.subtitle: Symbol of the return loop
meaning: Highlights the cycle: 'never again' turns into 'again'.
when: After a breakup when therapy or drastic change is promised immediately.
When the meeting schedule looks like a sine wave.
Right after the victim states boundaries or ultimatums.
action: Write down conditions for return and schedule a progress review date.

13.title: Thirteen
13.subtitle: Symbol of rupture and alarm
meaning: Announces a drastic cut-off often used as a threat.
May signal escalation toward economic or legal abuse.
when: When the abuser threatens custody or asset seizure.
As the victim prepares to leave or disclose evidence.
Right before major events: holidays, contracts, moving.
action: Alert a trusted person about potential escalation.
Draft a safety plan and review local resources.

resources.title: Recommended actions
resources.financialHelp: Contact your local social services for free financial support options.
resources.reportAbuse: Report institutional abuse to an ombudsperson or watchdog organisation.
resources.emotionalSupport: Schedule a conversation with a counsellor or helpline to process your emotions.
resources.boundaries: Practice boundary-setting with a trusted person and prepare assertive responses.
resources.psychologicalHelp: Consider individual therapy to rebuild self-esteem and resilience.
resources.documentation: Collect evidence (screenshots, notes) documenting abusive interactions.
resources.safetyPlan: Create a safety plan with safe locations and people you can reach out to.
resources.digitalSecurity: Update passwords, enable two-factor authentication and limit device access.
resources.legalAdvice: Seek free legal advice from a civic advice centre or legal aid.
resources.trustedPerson: Share the situation with someone you trust to gain support and witnesses.
resources.communitySupport: Join an online or local support community experienced with psychological abuse.

sin_1.title: Taking institutional money instead of real help
sin_1.desc: A toxic person exploits institutional resources for personal gain instead of offering real support to the partner or family. Money matters more than the needs of people in crisis.
sin_1.example_1: A partner takes social benefits meant for the survivor but never pays for therapy.
sin_1.example_2: A relative pushes you to take a loan in their name to get a bank bonus, ignoring family debt.
sin_1.example_3: A caregiver controls a child’s account to spend the childcare allowance on themselves.
sin_1.q_1: Does someone close collect benefits or grants but refuse to spend them on your needs?
sin_1.help_1: Covers housing allowances, therapy funds or crisis scholarships.
sin_1.q_2: How often do you have to justify how support funds should be used?
sin_1.help_2: Think about the last six months.
sin_1.q_3: What financial actions does this person take?
sin_1.q_3.opt_1: Signs paperwork without consent to speed up payouts.
sin_1.q_3.opt_2: Urges you to hide information from institutions.
sin_1.q_3.opt_3: Moves money to their account and blocks access.
sin_1.q_4: How much control do you have over spending support money?
sin_1.q_5: Have you ever lost access to support because someone else controlled the funds?

result.low: Financial abuse risk is low, yet keep tracking transactions and store receipts.
result.medium: There are signs someone redirects support funds. Plan budgets together and seek financial counselling.
result.high: Severe financial misuse detected. Contact the institution providing aid and seek legal support quickly.

sin_2.title: Blame shifting and playing the victim
sin_2.desc: The toxic person casts themselves as the victim to avoid responsibility and trigger guilt. They twist the story so you apologise for their behaviour.
sin_2.example_1: After a fight they claim they shouted only because your silence provoked them.
sin_2.example_2: They tell family you are aggressive even though they started the conflict.
sin_2.example_3: They post on social media about being victimised so everyone turns against you.
sin_2.q_1: Do you often hear it is your fault even when facts say otherwise?
sin_2.q_2: How often does the person describe you as the troublemaker to others?
sin_2.q_3: What blaming tactics do you notice?
sin_2.q_3.opt_1: Bringing up past mistakes to silence you.
sin_2.q_3.opt_3: Exaggerating their suffering to gain sympathy.
sin_2.q_4: Do you end up apologising even when you did nothing wrong?
sin_2.q_5: How supported do you feel when blame shifting happens?

result.low: You recognise the manipulation and keep perspective. Stay in touch with allies who validate your view.
result.medium: Blame shifting distorts accountability. Prepare factual examples and seek mediator support.
result.high: Constant blame erodes your self-worth. Consult a therapist and consider limiting contact.

sin_3.title: Gaslighting
sin_3.desc: Gaslighting undermines your memory and reality. The abuser makes you doubt your experiences to gain control.
sin_3.example_1: You are told you are “overreacting” even though the conversation was full of insults.
sin_3.example_2: Evidence on your phone disappears and they insist it never existed.
sin_3.example_3: They tell others you have mental issues to discredit you.
sin_3.q_1: Does someone tell you that you misremember events?
sin_3.q_2: How often are your feelings dismissed as exaggeration?
sin_3.q_3.opt_3: Mocking your memory or mental health.
sin_3.q_4: How confident do you feel when sharing your memories?
sin_3.q_5: Do you withdraw from conversations to avoid being questioned again?

result.low: You have tools to confirm your memories. Keep documenting and rely on facts.
result.medium: Gaslighting shakes your stability. Keep a log of events and review it with trusted people.
result.high: Gaslighting is severe and harms your mental health. Seek professional help and secure evidence.

sin_4.title: Surveillance and obsessive control
sin_4.desc: The toxic person tracks every move, violates privacy and demands total control over your time. It is a boundary violation and abuse.
sin_4.example_1: They expect immediate replies and call every few minutes.
sin_4.example_2: They install spyware on your phone or computer.
sin_4.q_1: Does someone expect you to be available all the time?
sin_4.q_2: How often are your devices or accounts checked?
sin_4.q_3: What control patterns do you see most?
sin_4.q_4: Can you freely decide who to meet and when?
sin_4.q_5: How often do you hide actions to avoid conflict?

result.low: You maintain healthy privacy boundaries. Keep clear agreements about time and contact.
result.medium: Control is limiting your freedom. Strengthen digital security and inform trusted people.
result.high: Surveillance is dangerous. Take immediate safety steps and seek legal guidance.

sin_5.title: Weaponising institutions
sin_5.desc: The toxic person manipulates institutions to intimidate and silence. False reports and legal threats are used to disrupt your life.
sin_5.example_2: Sending false statements to your child’s school to undermine your care.
sin_5.example_3: Threatening lawsuits if you speak about the abuse.
sin_5.q_1: Have you faced unfounded complaints or reports?
sin_5.q_2: How often do you have to explain yourself to institutions because of accusations?
sin_5.q_3: What institutional tactics are used against you?
sin_5.q_4: Do you avoid seeking help for fear of retaliation?
sin_5.q_5: How often do you consult a lawyer because of these actions?

result.low: Things are manageable but record every institutional contact.
result.medium: Institutions are becoming a pressure tool. Prepare documentation and get legal advice.
result.high: Severe misuse of law detected. Find legal representation immediately and inform an advocate.

sin_6.title: Emotional blackmail and threats
sin_6.desc: Emotional blackmail evokes fear and makes you feel responsible for someone else’s emotions. Threats are used to force compliance.
sin_6.example_1: You hear that tragedy will happen if you leave.
sin_6.example_2: They threaten to expose compromising information unless you obey.
sin_6.example_3: They promise self-harm if you do not agree with them.
sin_6.q_1: Does someone threaten to hurt themselves or you to get their way?
sin_6.q_2: How often do you feel fear about their reaction?
sin_6.q_3: What types of emotional blackmail occur?
sin_6.q_4: Do you avoid decisions because of possible retaliation?
sin_6.q_5: How often do you seek help from others when blackmail happens?

result.low: You recognise blackmail attempts and set boundaries. Keep coordinating support with trusted allies.
result.medium: Blackmail influences your decisions. Consider therapy and plan safety responses.
result.high: Threat levels are severe. Contact emergency services and support organisations immediately.

sin_7.title: Creating chaos and disinformation
sin_7.desc: The toxic person deliberately creates confusion to keep you off balance. Rules change constantly and information contradicts itself.
sin_7.example_1: Plans are changed last minute without notice.
sin_7.example_2: You receive conflicting updates about key decisions.
sin_7.example_3: They tell different stories to different people to spark conflict.
sin_7.q_1: Is it hard to know the facts because information keeps changing?
sin_7.q_2: How often do you get contradictory messages?
sin_7.q_3.opt_1: Changing dates or rules without warning.
sin_7.q_5: Do you need others to confirm what was agreed?

result.low: You keep chaos in check. Continue documenting agreements in writing.
result.medium: Disinformation begins to sway your choices. Use written confirmations and involve witnesses.
result.high: Chaos is used as a control tool. Set clear communication rules and seek mediation.

sin_8.title: Sowing division and breaking bonds
sin_8.desc: The abuser isolates you from allies, fuels conflicts and restricts access to support to weaken your safety net.
sin_8.example_1: They badmouth your friends so you stop seeing them.
sin_8.example_2: Family members are turned against each other via rumours.
sin_8.example_3: You are forced to choose “them or me”.
sin_8.q_1: Does someone control who you can spend time with?
sin_8.q_2: How often do you feel pressure to reduce contact with loved ones?
sin_8.q_3: What bond-breaking actions do you notice?
sin_8.q_4: Do you have space to build your own support network?
sin_8.q_5: How often do you hide meetings with loved ones?

result.low: Your relationships remain stable. Nurture regular contact with supporters.
result.medium: Isolation tactics appear. Set boundaries and inform allies about manipulation.
result.high: Strong isolation efforts require action. Reach out to support groups and rebuild connections.

gaslighting.label: Gaslighting
gaslighting.description: Twisting reality to make you doubt your perception.
gaslighting.tip: Write down facts or ask a trusted person to reality-check.

blameShift.label: Blame shifting
blameShift.description: Placing responsibility for their behaviour onto you.
blameShift.tip: State the observable behaviour and keep responsibilities clear.

triangulation.label: Triangulation
triangulation.description: Using third parties to pressure or control the narrative.
triangulation.tip: Limit indirect channels and engage only in safe, direct conversations.

loveBombing.label: Love bombing
loveBombing.description: Overwhelming affection or promises to regain control.
loveBombing.tip: Look for consistent actions rather than grand declarations.

guiltTripping.label: Guilt tripping
guiltTripping.description: Invoking guilt to push you into compliance.
guiltTripping.tip: Name the tactic and reaffirm your boundaries.

futureFaking.label: Future faking
futureFaking.description: Dangling hypothetical plans to keep you attached.
futureFaking.tip: Focus on what is happening now, not on promises of tomorrow.

responses.welcome: I'm only trying to help. Tell me what's on your mind.

blameShift.yourFault: This is your fault — if you behaved better we wouldn't have any problems.

triangulation.everyone: Even our friends say you're the difficult one here.

loveBombing.promises: I promise I'll change overnight, just give me another chance.

guiltTripping.sacrifice: After everything I've sacrificed for you, this is how you repay me?

futureFaking.plans: Why are you upset? I already planned our future house and wedding.
